Award.AwardTitle: IBSS: Measuring Justice, Managing Equity: An Interdisciplinary, Multi-Level Approach to Understanding Bias and Equity in Police Stops and Use of Force

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on what causes racial disparities in policing and how one can measure these disparities using tools taken from sociology, demography, public policy, criminology, psychology, and behavioral economics. Understanding what causes contemporary racial inequality is particularly vexing for researchers across disciplines because the US's steady decline in racial prejudice has not been accompanied by an analogous decline in racial inequality across social institutions (e.g., education, healthcare, employment, criminal justice). This has meant that traditional theories of how racial inequality is produced are insufficient to explain contemporary racial dynamics, requiring new research models to produce new understandings of social inequality. This project capitalizes on existing research collaborations between the Consortium for Police Leadership in Equity and law enforcement departments across the US to produce a mixed-methods approach to understanding what produces racial inequality in complex systems (i.e., policing). In cooperation with approximately 25 law enforcement partners, the investigators will first standardize data collection regarding police stops of pedestrians and motorists as well as police use of force. Second, researchers will collect psychological surveys from officers, aggregating responses by districts within departments. Finally, using social-spatial data, department policy data, aggregate officer attitude data, and data about the relative contributions of "bad apples" to department-wide disparity rates, the researchers will address some of the fundamental questions about race in law enforcement as well as the role that local demographics and department-wide culture have in producing racial inequality. The interdisciplinary research team and large number of participating police departments facilitate inquiry across multiple levels of analysis and comparisons across different types of departments, producing a symptomology of unequal outcomes. While previous research has looked at police-citizen encounters (stops, searches, arrests, force, etc.) or measured biases, it has rarely done both together. Consequently, this project will contribute both to scientific understandings of what causes racial inequality in policing and identifying ways practitioners can measure and manage that inequality.

Taken together, the investigators intend this project to promote the development and validation of a nationally standardized approach to police stops and use of force data collection, analysis, and interpretation. The findings will be widely disseminated to police departments, directly informing policy and setting the scientific foundations for national best practices to reduce racial inequality in police outcomes. This project will also provide postdoctoral fellows and graduate students a unique opportunity to examine racial bias in an applied and multidisciplinary context, while exposing them to more complex and diverse data analytic strategies. This project is supported through the NSF Interdisciplinary Behavioral and Social Sciences Research (IBSS) competition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With generous support from the National Science Foundation, the Center for Policing Equity (CPE) has established the National Justice Database (NJD) which tracks incident-level data related to police-citizen interactions (most notably vehicle stops, pedestrian stops and use of force events). These incident-level data are integrated with department climate survey data, related to variation in department policies, and benchmarked against local crime data and population demographics to create a uniquely large and comprehensive database. By integrating these data, we can identify the specific mechanisms of policing that lead to more or less unequal outcomes, with an explicit focus on contributions of individual officers and local practices of law enforcement to racial disparities.

The work of the NJD has cultivated a number of intellectual and societal contributions. First, by incorporating departmental climate survey data into the NJD, we can assess how officer attitudes relate to police behaviors in the field. This process, known as Attitude-Behavior Matching, allows us to assess how officer attitudes on a range of topics (e.g., community perceptions, mental health, and physical wellness) relate to their policing behaviors (e.g., use of force and stops behaviors). This tool is unique to CPE and provides an innovative analytic approach for social science research. This tool also provides a model for other disciplines seeking to examine how attitudes relate to behavior.

The NJD analytic plan for the reports we deliver to law enforcement agencies has provided a model for writing impactful comparative reports that use regional and nationwide data. The plan identifies 40 key analyses that correspond to the research questions we aim to answer in each report. As we continue to deliver reports to more law enforcement agencies across the county, we have created a rubric that will help us more accurately conduct national comparisons regarding what constitutes normal, low, and high amounts of disparities compared to similar departments across the country. Although we’ve utilized this analytic framework within the context of policing, this framework can be extended beyond policing to other domains (e.g., public health and education).

The NJD policy analysis framework provides a more efficient map for engaging in policy review and analysis. Through refinement of our policy analysis plan, we have developed a method for systematically quantifying department policy variance more quickly. This method removes layers of intensive labor that is traditionally inherent to policy review processes. Improving upon the efficiency of our policy review methods has increased our capacity to deliver policy reports to more agencies. Optimizing this process enables us to deliver policy recommendations to more partner agencies and provides them with valuable insights into how they can revise current departmental policy to promote more equitable outcomes for the communities they serve. A number of departments have begun revising their policies based on our policy report recommendations, in turn creating opportunities for improved policy-community relations. The NJD policy analysis framework also allows us to examine how variation in departmental policy in regards to clarity, prescriptiveness, robustness, and particular practices (e.g., limits on high-speed vehicle pursuits) maps onto variation in departmental outcomes (e.g., use of force). These robust analyses will provide a proof of concept that can be generalized to the broader policing policy landscape and beyond.

One of the most significant accomplishments of the NJD has been the completion of version 1.0 of our NJD processing software. We worked with a team of Google engineers to design and build custom software that audits, normalizes, and annotates police data in a fraction of the time that it previously took to do by hand. With this tool, we can identify potential problems in the data (e.g., missing variables, temporal gaps in incident data, indecipherable variable names). This software also allows us to integrate departmental data with census data by utilizing the Google Maps API to geo-locate police incidents and correspond them to census tracts. From there, the tool accesses the Census API to fetch census tract demographic data for the corresponding incident – a key factor in enabling analyses that examine racial disparities across locales. This tool has allowed us to deliver reports to more police partners, thus maximizing opportunities to provide police departments with recommendations on how they can move towards more equitable policing outcomes for the communities they serve.   

The NJD project has made significant strides in providing law enforcement agencies with the tools they need in order to promote fair and equitable policing practices. Through the refinement of our analytic frameworks and technology innovation, we maximize our ability to provide police departments with recommendations on best practices for procedurally just policing. The ability to provide these reports to more law enforcement agencies across the country at a regular cadence allows us to move the needle forward on police reform and improving police-community relations.
